pr_title: Change Trino to match Hive on column rename/drop/add

timeline.message:
Change Trino to match Hive on column rename/drop/add

This commit changes the behavior of Trino to match Hive when columns are renamed,
added or dropped.  Specifically:

* ORC transactional tables were changed to by default find columns by
  column index rather than by name.  ORC non-transactional tables already
  found columns by column index by default.
* Parquet was changed to by default find columns by name rather
  than by column index.
* The Hive config parameter partition_use_column_names, which is used only for ORC
  and Parquet, has been eliminated because it was redundant once the default
  settings for ORC and Parquet were changed to match Hive behavior.

Before this change, if the name of a top-level column in a Hive ORC transactional
table was changed, a subsequent Trino query would not see column data inserted before
the name change, but Hive would see the old data.  After this change, if column names
in old data files differ from column names from the metastore, by default Trino like
Hive will still see the old column values.  This default behavior can be changed by
setting session parameter hive.orc-use-column-names = true.

Similarly, before this change, if the name of a top-level column in a Hive Parquet
table was changed, a subsequent Trino query would see column data inserted before
the name change, but Hive returns null.  After this change, if column names read
from the Parquet data file differ from column names from the metastore, Trino
returns null for renamed column, matching Hive's behavior.  This default behavior
can be changed by setting session parameter hive.parquet-use-column-names = false.

This commit does not address differences between Trino and Hive
in response to column type changes.  This commit also does not address
name or type changes inside complex types like ROW.

The bulk of this commit is a collection of tests that verify Hive
and Trino behavior.
